text:
SIX
The Nazca Ridge and uplift of the 
Fitzcarrald Arch: implications for regional 
geology in northern South America

Nicolas Espurt1, Patrice Baby2, Stéphane Brusset2, Martin Roddaz2,
Wilber Hermoza3 and Jocelyn Barbarand4

1Université Paul Cézanne, Aix en Provence, France
2Université de Toulouse, France
3REPSOL-YPF, Madrid, Spain
4Université Paris Sud, France
The Fitzcarrald Arch corresponds to a NE–SW-trending widespread dissected relief of about 400,000 km2

located to the east of the sub-Andean thrust front. Analyses of drainage maps demonstrate that this regional 
uplift controls the modern Amazonian drainage network. During the Miocene, the Fitzcarrald Arch did not 
exist and this area corresponded to the subsiding foredeep of the Amazonian foreland basin. Analyses of the 
Miocene deposits outcropping within the Fitzcarrald Arch area indicate that deposition was controlled by 
tidal current and consisted of tide-dominated deltas and estuaries. The tidal Miocene deposits were followed 
by ﬂ uvial conglomerate and sandstone sediments, probably Pliocene to Pleistocene in age. Modelling of the 
vitrinite reﬂ ectance data shows that the uplift of the Fitzcarrald Arch began in Pliocene times; this date is 
further conﬁ rmed by sedimentary evidence such as provenance and a change of palaeocurrent directions from 
the Pliocene and Pleistocene record. Geophysical data show that the Fitzcarrald Arch uplift superimposed on 
the eastern part of the Nazca Ridge ﬂ at slab segment. The ﬂ at subduction process linked to the buoyancy of the 
Nazca Ridge has been active since ~4 Ma. Thus, the coincidence of the initiation of ﬂ at slab subduction with 
the Pliocene uplift of the Fitzcarrald Arch implies that the ﬂ at subduction of the Nazca Ridge is the cause of 
uplift. The Nazca Ridge ﬂ at subduction is the process responsible for the modern conﬁ guration of the Amazon 
drainage basin and may be one of the decisive factors that triggered large-scale modiﬁ cation of the Amazonian 
landscape inducing drastic biota changes in the Amazonian basin during the last 4 million years.

The Fitzcarrald Arch is a major geomorphic feature of about 
400,000 km2 in the landscape of the Amazon drainage basin. It 
divides the northern Amazonian foreland basin from the southern 
Amazonian foreland basin, both of which are driven by Andean oro-
genic loading (Roddaz et al. 2005). The Fitzcarrald Arch makes the 
Amazon foreland basin an atypical foreland basin, not like the four-
component model of DeCelles & Giles (1996) (see also Chapter 5).
The causes of the appearance of Fitzcarrald Arch regional uplift 
are the subject of active discussion. Some authors have proposed

Amazonia, Landscape and Species Evolution: A Look into the Past,
1st edition. Edited by C. Hoorn and F.P. Wesselingh. 
© 2010 Blackwell Publishing

alternative hypotheses for the Fitzcarrald Arch uplift: surface 
expression of inherited Paleozoic heterogeneities (Jacques 2003; 
Carlotto et al. 2007), simple mega-fan geometry (Picard et al.
2008) or a relatively higher stress regime above a subduction zone 
(Dumont 1996). Based on geomorphic, geophysical and geody-
namic evidence, Espurt et al. (2007) have demonstrated that the 
high elevation of the Fitzcarrald Arch was caused by the ﬂ at slab 
subduction of the aseismic Nazca Ridge below northern South 
America. These authors estimated the uplift of the Fitzcarrald 
Arch to be no older than Pliocene (Espurt et al. 2007).
This chapter reviews the criteria that permitted Espurt et al.
(2007) to link the subduction of the aseismic Nazca Ridge and 
the uplift of the Fitzcarrald Arch. We also constrained better spa-
tial and time relationships between the Nazca Ridge subduction 
and the Fitzcarrald Arch uplift in the Amazonian foreland basin,

Le Roux et al. 2000; Hampel 2002; Clift et al. 2003), and ~800 m
maximum uplift of Pliocene-Pleistocene marine terraces (Hsu 
1992; Macharé & Ortlieb 1992; Saillard 2008; Wipf et al. 2008). 
The Cordillera Blanca region (Central Andes), located northwards 
of the present-day Nazca Ridge subducted segment, shows recent 
extensional collapses in a prethickened continental crust, which 
are interpreted as the consequence of the underplating of the 
Nazca Ridge (McNulty & Farber 2002). In addition, the southward 
migration of the Nazca Ridge is recorded by Neogene counterclock-
wise rotations in the Eastern Cordillera (Rousse et al. 2003). The 
eastern continuation of the Nazca Ridge is marked by a seismic 
gap observed at the sub-Andes–Amazonian foreland boundary 
(Gutscher et al. 1999; Hampel 2002), which coincides spatially with 
the relief of the Fitzcarrald Arch (see Fig. 6.1) (Espurt et al. 2007).

through addition of new geomorphic, sedimentological and well 
log data. The consequences of the Nazca Ridge subduction and 
the related Fitzcarrald Arch uplift on the modern Amazonian 
basin evolution and its related biota are then discussed.

The Nazca Ridge is one of the major oceanic ridges subducting 
below the South American plate (Fig. 6.1). This ridge has an average 
bathymetric relief of 1.5 km above the adjacent sea ﬂ oor of the Nazca 
Plate, a maximum width of 200 km at its base, and an average crustal 
thickness of 18 ± 3 km (Woods & Okal 1994; Tassara et al. 2006). 
The Nazca Ridge formed from the activity of a hotspot located near 
the Paciﬁ c spreading ridge (Pilger 1981), and the Tuamotu mirror 
ridge is visible on the eastern Paciﬁ c Plate (Gutscher et al. 1999). 
The ridge migrates southwards below the South American Plate 
because the ridge segment is N45°E trending, oblique to the N78° 
present-day plate convergence (Gripp & Gordon 2002). The Nazca 
Ridge subduction beneath the Peruvian coast started 11.2 Ma at 11°S 
(Hampel 2002), and constitutes the southern edge of the Peruvian 
ﬂ at slab segment (Gutscher et al. 1999).

Morphological records, drainage system and crustal 
structure of the Fitzcarrald area

The structural and morphological Fitzcarrald Arch includes a 
large part of the western Amazon drainage basin (see Fig. 6.1). The 
Fitzcarrald Arch forms a WSW–ENE-trending upland in south-
eastern Peru and western Brazil that covers about 400 000 km2, 
i.e. ~15% of the total surface of the Amazon ﬂ oodplain (Guyot 
et al. 2007). The Fitzcarrald Arch develops east of the sub- Andean 
thrust front and south of the Contaya-Moa thrusts, where no 
thrust deformation occurs (Fig. 6.2a). It develops between the 
northwestern Ucayali sub-basin to the northeast, and Madre de 
Dios sub-basin to the southeast, and is bounded to the northeast by 
the Acre sub-basin (Kronberg et al. 1998; see also Chapter 3). The 
Fitzcarrald Arch displays a higher mean elevation surface (~615 m 
asl [above sea level]) compared to its bounding Ucayali and Madre 
de Dios sub-basins (~120 m asl and ~150 m asl, respectively).
The Fitzcarrald Arch forms a main drainage divide (Church 
1901; Dumont 1996; Espurt et al. 2007; Regard et al. 2009) between 
the Ucayali sub-basin, the Acre sub-basin and the Madre de Dios 
sub-basin. The drainage network has been digitized from Shuttle 
Radar Topographic Mission (SRTM) digital elevation model 
90 m using the TAS freeware (Terrain Analysis System; Lindsay 
2005). Seventy-one sub-basins of seventh order, representing an 
average area of ~3660 km2, have been deﬁ ned on the Fitzcarrald 
Arch (see Fig. 6.2a) according to Strahler’s method (1952) (see 
Regard et al. 2009 for more details). The mean orientation and 
elongation of each sub-basin have been measured. At a large scale, 
the Fitzcarrald Arch disturbs the present-day drainage network of 
the Amazon basin in generating an asymmetrical radial drainage. 
The main part of the drainage network displays a northeasterly 
direction (average value of N52°E; see Fig. 6.2b), toward the Acre 
sub-basin. The Fitzcarrald Arch divides the drainage basin of
the Ucayali to the northwest, and that of the Madre de Dios to the 
southeast. The apex of the drainage divide is located east of the 
sub-Andean thrust front, at roughly 10.5°S, 72.5°W (see Fig. 6.2a). 
Most of the basins located west of the apex exhibit drainage direc-
tions towards the Andes (see Fig. 6.2a,b). At a local scale, seventh-
order sub-basins develop on tilted Miocene and Pliocene surface 
bedding (Espurt et al. 2007; Regard et al. 2009). These sub-basins 
have elongated surfaces and are poorly organized with parallel 
and subparallel patterns (see Fig. 6.2a).

The southward migration of the Nazca Ridge between 11°S and 17°S 
has been recorded in the geomorphology and tectonics of the Peruvian 
Andes (see Fig. 6.1). Along the forearc region, the ridge migration 
generated N–S variations of the rates of subsidence and erosion of 
the coastal margin (von Huene & Suess 1988; von Huene et al. 1996;

Fig. 6.1 Geomorphic map of western South America. The 
dashed black line shows the boundary of the Amazon drain-
age basin (modiﬁ ed from Guyot et al. 2007). The Fitzcarrald 
Arch divides the western Amazonian foreland basin into two 
parts: the northern Amazonian foreland basin (NAFB) and 
the southern Amazonian foreland basin (SAFB). To the east, 
the arch is bound by the intracratonic Amazonian basins 
(EAB). The plate convergence vector is from Gripp & Gordon 
(2002). The projection of the Nazca Ridge beneath the South 
American plate is from Hampel (2002).

The Fitzcarrald Arch exposes mainly Miocene and Pliocene 
sedimentary deposits, whose bedding is parallel to the topographic 
surface (see Fig. 6.2a). Dip of the bedding has been measured along 
regional topographic cross-sections from the SRTM digital eleva-
tion model (see Fig. 6.2a). The eastern Brazilian ﬂ ank of the arch 
shows low-magnitude bedding dipping ~0.02° to the ENE. On the 
northwestern Ucayali ﬂ ank of the Arch, bedding dips ~0.3° north-
westwards. The most prominent tilted bedding surface is found 
near the Ucayali River. This surface connects down with the Ucayali 
River and tops thick Pliocene conglomerate deposits (Dumont et al. 
1991; Räsänen et al. 1995). The surface tilting seems to postdate the 
drainage over the surface of several tributaries of the Ucayali River 
(Dumont et al. 1991). The northern ﬂ ank of the Fitzcarrald Arch is 
greatly incised and exhibits mainly Miocene strata. In contrast, the 
southeastern Madre de Dios ﬂ ank of the arch presents more gently 
tilted bedding dipping ~0.1° to the southeast (see Fig. 6.2a).
The NW–SE-trending regional seismic reﬂ ection proﬁ le provided 
by PeruPetro S.A. (see Fig. 6.2c) shows that the Fitzcarrald Arch 
forms a bulge of lithospheric-scale wavelength (340 km minimum).

Fig. 6.2 (a) Map of the seventh-order drainage sub-basins of the Fitzcarrald Arch area. The background corresponds to a 
digital elevation model from Shuttle Radar Topographic Mission (SRTM) 90 m data. Basins are bounded by white lines. The 
apex of the drainage sub-basins of the Fitzcarrald Arch is shown by the black star. The main structural features are shown. 
(b) Rose diagram of the modern drainage orientations of the drainage sub-basins of order 7. (c) Seismic reﬂ ection proﬁ le A–A’ 
of the Fitzcarrald Arch uplift showing the very-long-wavelength bending of the subsurface sediments of the Fitzcarrald Arch. 
The dashed black line shows the supposed top of the Miocene strata. SW, Sepa well; MW, Mashansha well; PW, Panguana well; 
PPW, Puerto Primo well; pjt, projected onto the seismic proﬁ le.
The Nazca Ridge and Fitzcarrald Arch  91

This bulge is underlain by ~2.5 km-thick Cretaceous and Cenozoic 
strata of nearly constant thickness. On this proﬁ le, the Paleozoic 
sedimentary basins, the Paleozoic thrusts (e.g. Paititi High) and other 
pre-Cretaceous structures (e.g. Manu Arch) are unconformably 
overlain by Cretaceous strata and present a local-scale wavelength of 
~100 km. These older structures, eroded and sealed by Cretaceous 
strata, have been subsequently uplifted and involved in the lithos-
pheric-scale structure of the Fitzcarrald Arch (Espurt et al. 2007). 
The Neogene sedimentary rocks are partially eroded and exposed 
in both ﬂ anks of the Fitzcarrald Arch. Thickness variations in the 
Neogene sediments, that could support a synsedimentary Neogene 
uplift of the Fitzcarrald Arch, are not found (see Fig. 6.2c).

Miocene to Pleistocene sedimentological record of the 
Fitzcarrald Arch area

We describe here outcrops of the Neogene succession in three rep-
resentative areas of the Fitzcarrald Arch (Fig. 6.3): the northwestern
Madre de Dios Fm (Late Miocene ~9 Ma)

Cenozoic undifferentiated, Mesozoic
and Palaeozoic rocks/structural highs

Fig. 6.3 Geological map of the Fitzcarrald Arch. Numbers 1–14 refer to locations of outcrops discussed in the text: 1, Mapuya 
River (Espurt et al. 2006; Antoine et al. 2007); 2, Sepa River; 3, Urubamba River; 4, Purus River (Räsänen et al. 1995, Hovikoski 
et al. 2008); 5, (Cozzuol, 2006); 6, Patos Inca (Cozzuol 2006); 7, Alto Purus River (Campbell et al. 2001); 8, Manú River; 9, Madre 
de Dios River; 10, Inambari River (Roddaz 2004; Roddaz et al. 2006; Hovikoski et al. 2005); 11, Tambo River; 12, Chicosillo River 
(Espurt et al. 2006); 13, Las Piedras River (Campbell et al. 2001); 14, Lower Madre de Dios River (Roddaz 2004); 15, Ucayali River 
(Dumont et al. 1991). Locations of the Mashansha well (MW), Sepa well (SW), Panguana well (PW) and Puerto Primo well (PTW) 
are shown. The location of the seismic proﬁ le of Fig. 6.2c is also shown. Fm, formation.

ﬂ ank of the arch exhibits late Middle Miocene deposits, which 
are well exposed along the Sepa, Urubamba, Inuya and Mapuya 
Rivers, where the arch is the most deeply incised (see Fig. 6.3). The 
strata of the Ipururo Formation are observed along the Mapuya 
River (10.43086°S, 73.05145°W) (Fig. 6.4a; see also Fig. 6.3) 
(Espurt et al. 2006). The base of the section is composed of sand-
stones exhibiting cyclic lateral variation of foreset thicknesses 
underlined by mud clasts, interpreted as tidal sand bar and sand-
stones, with calcrete concretions interpreted as palaeosol deposits 
(see Fig. 6.4b). Palaeocurrents measured from foresets are mainly 
to the east. These sandy deposits are eroded by ~1.5 m-thick

ﬂ ank of the arch (Ucayali sub-basin) where the oldest sediments 
outcrop; the northeastern ﬂ ank of the arch (Acre sub-basin); and 
the southeastern ﬂ ank of the arch (Madre de Dios sub-basin).

The oldest sediments outcropping on the Fitzcarrald Arch 
area are Miocene in age and part of the Ipururo and Madre de 
Dios Formations in Peru (Kummel 1948), and of the Solimões 
Formation in Brazil (Oppenheim 1946; Silva 1988). The northern

Tidal sand bars
Fluvial
Tidal deposits

Fig. 6.4 (a) Representative section, from the Mapuya and Chicosillo Rivers on the northern ﬂ ank of the Fitzcarrald Arch, of 
the Miocene deposits and unconformable Pliocene and Pleistocene syntectonic deposits (see detail in text). (b) Details of the 
basal conglomerates with wood fragments. (c) Detail of the tidal deposits showing mud-sand couplets deﬁ ning tidal bundles, 
mud drapes and double mud drapes characteristic of tidal deposits. (d) Pliocene conglomerate deposits (Chicosillo River). (e) 
Aggradational Pleistocene terrace deposits eroding the Neogene strata (Chicosillo River). Fm, formation; Pleis, Pleistocene; A, 
clay; Sf, ﬁ ne sand; Sm, medium sand; Sg, coarse sand; Cg, conglomerate; SU, unconformity surface.

the tidal deposits – probably the same as dated by Campbell 
et al. (2001) in the Purus River – gives an estimated age at 9.31 ± 
3.39 Ma (apatite ﬁ ssion track dating; Roddaz 2004; see Fig. 6.3)
near Puerto Maldonado along the Madre de Dios River (12.5823°S, 
69.21098°W).
Late Middle-Late Miocene deposits show similar dominance of 
a tide-dominated depositional environment in the whole of the 
Fitzcarrald Arch area. The tides indicate sea-level setting as con-
ﬁ rmed by pedogenically altered intervals (Hovikoski et al. 2008). 
Consequently, from the late Middle Miocene to the Late Miocene, 
the Fitzcarrald Arch area was completely ﬂ ooded and its sediment 
deposition was controlled by tidal currents.

channel-shaped conglomerates (lithofacies Gt, sensu Miall 1996) 
(see Fig. 6.4b), which can be laterally replaced by planar cross-bed-
ded sandstones (lithofacies Sp, sensu Miall 1996). The conglom-
erates contain sandstone and mudstone clasts, less than 5 cm in 
diameter, wood fragments and high concentrations of vertebrate 
fossils and teeth (Antoine et al. 2007; Salas-Gismondi et al. 2007), 
incorporated in a sandy matrix. The overlying interval is ~1.8 m 
thick and consists of alternating mud and sand layers exhibiting 
mud-sand couplets interpreted as tidal bundles (see Fig. 6.4c). 
Mud drapes and double mud drapes as well as cyclic variations 
of the bundles are frequent and characterize tide-controlled 
deposition (Nio & Yang 1991). In the lower part of this interval, 
the sands exhibit mud-sand couplets with opposite bidirectional
stratiﬁ cations (‘herring-bone’ cross-stratiﬁ cations) and ﬂ aser to 
lenticular bedding. Reactivation surfaces as well as mud drapes 
and double mud drapes are common. The palaeocurrent direc-
tions are dominantly towards the northeast and southwest 
(see Fig. 6.4c). These deposits are commonly bioturbated. In 
the upper part of this interval, type 2 climbing ripples (Jopling 
& Walker 1986) with sigmoid stratiﬁ cation (Mutti et al. 1985) 
underlain by mud clasts are frequent and indicate tide-controlled
deposition (Nio & Yang 1991). The sedimentary succession 
ends with mud and sand tidal rhythmites followed by palaeosol 
deposits in the top (see Fig. 6.4a).
The diverse vertebrate Mapuya fauna (~30 taxa; Antoine et al.
2007; Salas-Gismondi et al. 2007) is strongly reminiscent of Late 
Middle Miocene Laventan faunas from Colombia, Venezuela and 
Brazil (13.5–11.8 Ma; Madden et al. 1997). In addition, a change 
in palaeomagnetic polarity data from normal to reverse provides 
a numerical age around 13 Ma, owing to Laventan biochronol-
ogy and Global Magnetic Polarity Time Scale (GMPTS) (Madden 
et al. 1997; Antoine et al. 2007).
On the eastern ﬂ ank of the Fitzcarrald Arch, the outcrops of the 
Solimões Formation have been described by Räsänen et al. (1995) 
and Hovikoski et al. (2008) along the Jurua and Acre Rivers and the 
Purus River (8.80610°S, 68.80330°W) (see Fig. 6.3). These Miocene 
sediments commonly consist of various types of tidally inﬂ uenced 
inclined heterolithic stratiﬁ cation (IHS)-bearing channel deposits 
that are intercalated with pedogenically altered horizons (Hovikoski 
et al. 2008). The palaeocurrents are variable between localities but 
are mainly toward the southeast and northeast (Räsänen et al.
1995; Hovikoski et al. 2007). The vertebrate faunal assemblage of 
the Neogene deposits of the Acre region indicates a Late Miocene 
age (Cozzuol 2006). The precise age of these deposits is estimated 
at 9.01 ± 0.28 Ma on the basis of argon-40/argon-39 (40Ar/39Ar) 
dating (mica and feldspar) of river level (Campbell et al. 2001; see 
Fig. 6.3) along the Purus River (10.41530 °S, 71.172799°W).
The southern ﬂ ank of the Fitzcarrald Arch displays Late Miocene 
deposits (Madre de Dios Formation) described by Roddaz 
(2004), Roddaz et al. (2004) and Hovikoski et al. (2005) along 
the Manú (11.90318°S, 71.39417°S), Madre de Dios (12.56787°S, 
70.10265°W) and Inambari Rivers (12.92209°S, 70.34911°W) 
(see Fig. 6.3). The sedimentary series displays a 10–40 m thick-
ness of several sharp based successions. The individual tidal point 
bars are ~3 m thick and consist of tide-dominated estuarine and 
delta deposits (Roddaz 2004; Roddaz et al. 2004; Hovikoski et al.
2005). The palaeocurrents are dominantly towarda the northeast, 
and towarda the east and west. A tuffaceous level dated within

The Pliocene deposits consist of coarse-grained alluvial fan and 
ﬂ uvial deposits, ascribed to the Juanjui/Corrientes Formations in 
the Ucayali sub-basin, and to the Mazuko Formation in the Madre 
de Dios sub-basin.
On the northern ﬂ ank of the Fitzcarrald Arch, along the Tambo 
and Chicosillo Rivers (10.66257°S, 73.70055°W; see Fig. 6.3), 
the Pliocene deposits unconformably overlie the Miocene tidal 
deposits along an erosional surface (subaerial unconformity) 
interpreted as a foreslope surface (see Fig. 6.4a) (Catuneanu et al.
1999; see also Chapter 5). They are ~40 to 50 m thick and con-
sist of unconsolidated conglomerates displaying well-rounded 
quartzite and volcanic pebbles and wood remains, included in a 
sandy matrix (see Fig. 6.4a,d). The pebbles are less than 15 cm 
in diameter and their volcanic and quartzite compositions indi-
cate an Andean provenance. This unconsolidated conglomerate 
is topped by a tuffaceous level not yet dated, sandy deposits and 
palaeosol muddy deposits. Palaeocurrent data from imbricate 
gravels indicate a ﬂ ow direction towards N355.
On the southern ﬂ ank of the arch, the Pliocene deposits consist of 
channel-shaped conglomerates (lithofacies Gt, sensu Miall 1996) with 
quartzite, volcanic and white sandstone pebbles and planar cross-
bedded sandstones (lithofacies Sp, sensu Miall 1996). The pebbles are 
from 1 to 5 cm in diameter. Conglomerates and sands are associated 
with red massive muds and silts and are locally bioturbated (Roddaz 
2004). Along the Piedras River (12.05330°S, 69.90170°W), these 
Pliocene deposits are dated at 3.12 ± 0.02 Ma (40Ar/39Ar dating on 
micas from a tuffaceous level; Campbell et al. 2001; see Fig. 6.3).
Like the Miocene sediments, the Pliocene deposits form a set 
of successive tilted and dissected morphostructural surfaces, like 
those evidenced by the digital elevation model of the Ucayali and 
Madre de Dios sub-basins (see Fig. 6.2a; Espurt et al. 2007). Field 
observations and image interpretation also indicate the uncon-
formable disposition of the Pliocene on Miocene strata, particu-
larly in the northern ﬂ ank of the arch (see Figs 6.3 & 6.4a). On 
the northern ﬂ ank of the arch, the age of the contact is not well 
constrained. However, the Pliocene age of these series is related 
to overlying Pleistocene terrace deposits made up of weathered 
conglomerates (Dumont et al. 1991). On the southern ﬂ ank of the 
arch, the age of the contact between Miocene and Pliocene strata 
is much better and is bracketed between ~9 and ~3 Ma.
The Pliocene deposits record a change in the geodynamic con-
text of the Amazon drainage basin from a ﬁ lled foreland basin

during the Miocene characterized by tidal deposits to an overﬁ lled 
foreland basin characterized by continental deposits (Roddaz 
2004). In the Fitzcarrald Arch area, the major unconformity 
developed at the base of the Pliocene deposits (see Figs 6.3 & 6.4a) 
is probably linked to the beginning of the arch uplift in Pliocene 
times (Espurt et al. 2006).

The Pleistocene deposits of the Fitzcarrald Arch correspond to the 
Upper Solimões Formation (Silva 1988) equivalent to the Ucayali 
Formation in the Ucayali sub-basin.
On the northern ﬂ ank of the Arch, along the Tambo River and 
particularly along the Chicosillo River (10.66884°S, 73.69917°W; 
see Fig. 6.3), the Pleistocene deposits form ~5–8 m-thick aggra-
dational terraces of pebbles made of quartzite and volcanic rocks, 
Miocene clasts of mudstones and sandstones, and continental 
Pliocene clasts of sandstones. The pebbles are included in a sandy 
and silty matrix (see Fig. 6.4a,e). The pebble imbrications indicate 
a main palaeocurrent direction of N250°. This direction is par-
allel to the present-day drainage direction of the Chicosillo River, 
which runs towards the west, i.e. towards the Andes. Dumont 
et al. (1991) mentioned a radiocarbon age of 8520 ± 440 years 
(10.59364°S, 73.91033°W and 10.73521°S, 73.60313°W) for 
stepped ﬂ oodplain Pleistocene terraces along the Urubamba and 
Ucayali Rivers (see Fig. 6.3). Along the Mapuya River (10.42422°S, 
73.05185°W), aggradational terraces located at about 50 m above 
the water level consist of ﬁ ne sediments, quartzitic pebbles, carbon 
debris and palaeosol deposits (see Fig. 6.3).
On the eastern ﬂ ank of the arch, Kronberg et al. (1998) 
described Late Pleistocene(?) sediments that consist of lacustrine 
clays interlayered with thin carbonate beds rich in gypsum levels 
and vertebrate fossils (see Fig. 6.3). These sediments are inter-
preted to be deposited in a ﬂ uvial-lacustrine environment with 
variable hydrological conditions (Kronberg et al. 1998).
These ﬂ uvial deposits suggest a depositional system similar to 
the present-day depositional system developed in the Fitzcarrald 
Arch area. These deposits are strongly controlled by recent vertical 
motions that are due to the uplift of the Fitzcarrald Arch.
Timing of the Fitzcarrald Arch uplift

The subsidence curve and the evolution of the subsidence and 
sedimentation rates through time can be estimated by thermal 
modelling of vitrinite reﬂ ectance (Ro) – see Sweeney & Burnham 
(1990) and Allen & Allen (2005) for more details. In this study, we 
modelled Ro data using the one-dimensional basin modelling tool 
Genex 4.0.3 (IFP/Beicip). These results have been obtained from 
Airy back-stripping of the sedimentary succession, by calculating 
the decompacted thickness of each lithology and age, and consid-
ering appropriate palaeobathymetric and erosion values, as well 
as the isostatic readjustment of each sedimentary unit. We con-
sidered a Cenozoic geothermal gradient of 24°C/km, which is an 
average value in foreland basins and similar to the value estimated 
for other Andean foreland basins (Husson & Moretti 2002). We 
used data of the Mashansha well located on the northern ﬂ ank of
The Nazca Ridge and Fitzcarrald Arch  95

the arch (10.47202°S, 73.38603°W, and 326 m asl) and the Puerto 
Primo well located on the southern ﬂ ank of the arch (12.10861°S, 
69.72861°W, and 303 m asl) (Fig. 6.5; see also Fig. 6.3). The dis-
tance between these two wells is ~439 km. We also used add-
itional data from the Sepa well (see Fig. 6.3) located ~60 km south 
of the Manshansha well. These data have been projected to the 
Mashansha well along the same stratigraphic levels.
The interpretation of the well diagraphies (see Fig. 6.5a) com-
pleted with ﬁ eld data permit recognition of the different Cenozoic 
formations. The southern Puerto Primo well shows a 1.7 km-thick 
Cenozoic pile that consists of, in ascending order: a 475 m thick-
ness of the Paleocene Huayabamba Formation; a 807 m thick-
ness of the Miocene Ipururo Formation; and 405 m thickness 
of the Miocene-Pliocene Madre de Dios Formation. In contrast, 
the Mashansha well only displays a 1 km-thick Cenozoic pile, 
which consists of: 35 m thickness of the Paleocene Yahuarango 
Formation; 67 m thickness of the Eocene-Early Oligocene Pozo 
Formation; 410 m thickness of the Late Oligocene-Miocene 
Chambira Formation; 474 m thickness of the Miocene Ipururo 
Formation, and ﬁ nally a 42 m thickness of Pleistocene alluvial 
deposits. When compared with the Puerto Primo well succession, 
the Late Miocene sediments of the Mashansha well are missing 
and have been eroded.
Ro data have been used to identify the unconformities and es-
timate the amount of denudation according to the geothermal 
gradient (Allen & Allen 2005). Ro data come from wood in late 
Middle Miocene outcrops near the Mashansha well (Mapuya 
River) and from Paleozoic strata of the Mashansha well coupled 
with additional Ro data of the Sepa well (see Fig. 6.5b) (Espurt 
2007). Thermal modelling of the Ro data shows a modelled 
curve with three jumps (see Fig. 6.5b), which can be correlated 
with three main unconformities and large stratigraphic gaps. The 
lower jump is correlated with the unconformity developed at the 
base of the Late Carboniferous series (see Espurt et al. 2008). The 
intermediate jump is correlated with the unconformity developed 
at the base of the Cretaceous series (see Jaimes & de Freitas 2006 
and references therein; see also Fig. 6.2c). Finally, the upper jump 
is correlated with the unconformity developed at the base of the 
Pliocene continental series (see Figs 6.3 & 6.4). The model shows 
that ~700 m thickness of Miocene series have been removed below 
the Pliocene unconformity.
Thermal data allow us to constrain the Cenozoic basin mod-
elling of the Fitzcarrald Arch area (see Fig. 6.5b). During the 
Paleocene-Oligocene period, the Amazonian foreland basins was 
occupied by ﬂ oodplain deposits (Wesselingh & Salo 2006). The 
sedimentation rates are about 10–25 m/million years and the sub-
sidence rates are low in the Fitzcarrald area. The occurrence of 
tidal deposits since the Middle Miocene is marked by an increase 
in the subsidence rates from 40 to 90 m/million years at the base 
of the Ipururo Formation and the sedimentation rate increased 
from 50 to ~160 m/million years. The Ipururo Formation accu-
mulated during a period of ongoing tectonic loading and recorded 
a strong increase of the sedimentation rate (see Chapter 5). This 
major change in the geodynamic context of the Amazonian fore-
land basins is related to the growth of the Andes and the eastern 
propagation of the sub-Andean thrust front (see Chapters 4 & 5). 
These results indicate that the Fitzcarrald Arch did not exist in 
Middle and Late Miocene times. Instead, the Fitzcarrald area was

4 Ma: Flat subduction and uplift of the FA

Fig. 6.6 (a) The Nazca Ridge subduction history and its 
 relation with the Amazonian foreland basin evolution. When 
the subduction of the Nazca Ridge started 11.2 Ma, the
The Nazca Ridge and Fitzcarrald Arch  97

a subsiding foredeep depozone (in the sense of DeCelles & Giles 
1996) and subject to Middle and Late Miocene marine incur-
sions. The lack of Upper Miocene and Pliocene sediment on the 
Mashansha well is evidence of Pliocene erosion of about 700 m 
caused by the uplift of the Fitzcarrald Arch during Pliocene times 
(see Fig. 6.5). Accordingly, the Puerto Primo well shows that this 
erosion is restricted to the Fitzcarrald Arch, as evidenced by the 
thickness of Late Miocene Madre de Dios Formation sediments 
(~405 m) deposited in a subsiding area adjacent to the Fitzcarrald 
Arch uplift (e.g. in the Madre de Dios sub-basin).

The reconstruction of the Nazca Ridge geometry beneath the South 
American lithosphere (Hampel 2002) indicates that the buoy-
ancy of the Nazca Ridge supports a current ~700 km-long ﬂ at 
slab segment (Espurt et al. 2007). This ﬂ at slab segment reaches 
the Amazonian foreland basin below the Fitzcarrald Arch uplift. 
Hampel (2002) showed that the Nazca Ridge subduction below the 
South American Plate started 11.2 Ma (Fig. 6.6a). The beginning of 
the ridge subduction coincides with the onset of the eastward over-
thrusting of the Eastern Cordillera and sub-Andean zone, north 
of the Fitzcarrald Arch (Hermoza et al. 2005). During the Miocene, 
the Amazonian foreland basin constituted a single four-component 
foreland basin system (sensu DeCelles & Giles 1996; see Fig. 6.6a). 
The Fitzcarrald Arch did not exist and the area was subsiding and to-
tally occupied by tide-dominated deltas and estuaries (see Fig. 6.6a).
At the same time, the product of the erosion of the Andes ﬁ lled the 
western Amazonian drainage basin (Roddaz 2004).
The buoyancy of the Nazca Ridge produced a ﬂ at subducting 
slab beginning ~4 Ma, according to the cessation of arc volcanism 
(see Fig. 6.6b) (Soler & Bonhomme 1990; Rosenbaum et al. 2005). 
The coincidence of the initiation of ﬂ at slab subduction (Gutscher 
et al. 2000) with uplift of the Fitzcarrald Arch leads us to inter-
pret the ﬂ at subduction of the Nazca Ridge as the cause of uplift 
(Espurt et al. 2007). Uplift of the Fitzcarrald Arch in Pliocene times 
is recorded by unconformities and by ~700 m of erosion within 
the arch area since ~5–4 Ma (see Fig. 6.6b). The Pliocene deposits

Fitzcarrald Arch area of the Amazonian foreland basin (AFB) 
was a subsiding foredeep and dominated by tide-dominated 
estuaries and deltas. (b) When the ﬂ at subduction began at 
about 4 Ma, the eastern edge of the Nazca Ridge reached 
the Amazonian foreland basin and provoked uplift of the 
Fitzcarrald Arch (FA) dividing the Amazonian foreland basin 
into two subsiding basins: the northern Amazonian fore-
land basin (NAFB) and the southern Amazonian foreland 
basin (SAFB). The Fitzcarrald Arch is eroded by the Pliocene 
ﬂ uvial system. The drainage system of the Amazon Basin is 
reorganized inducing speciation of the freshwater ﬁ sh (see 
Chapter 17). (c) Present-day architecture of the Amazonian 
drainage basin and the denudation of the Fitzcarrald Arch by 
the modern drainage system. Dashed arrows indicate drain-
age orientations. Reconstruction of the Nazca Ridge path is 
from Hampel (2002). EAB, eastern and central Amazonian 
intracratonic basins; SAZ, sub-Andean Zone; IA, Iquitos Arc.

ﬂ ora in drier soils (Haffer 1997; Daly & Mitchell 2000; Saatchi 
et al. 2008). Through its action as a drainage divide since the 
Pliocene, the Fitzcarrald Arch uplift has probably controlled the 
speciation of aquatic populations (see Fig. 6.6b), as the freshwater 
ﬁ shes on either side of the arch started to diverge ~4 Ma (Hubert 
et al. 2006). Thus we hypothesize that the Fitzcarrald Arch played 
a major role in increasing spatial Pliocene-Pleistocene biodiver-
sity in the Amazon drainage basin.

have been progressively uplifted and warped on the southeastern 
side of the arch by its continuing growth, which is probably still 
active today (see Fig. 6.6c). This recent uplift is also consistent 
with the change of the palaeocurrent directions observed between 
the Pliocene and Pleistocene deposits and the abnormal west-
ward present-day drainage of some rivers towards the Andes (see 
Figs 6.2 & 6.6c).

Consequences of the Fitzcarrald Arch uplift on 
Amazonian basin evolution and its biota

This research project was carried out thanks to the Institut 
de Recherche pour le Développement-PeruPetro SA research 
agreement, and supported by IRD (UR 154) and the French 
Institut National des Sciences de l’Univers – Centre National 
de la Recherche Scientiﬁ que programs DyETI (Dynamique 
et Evolution de la Terre Interne) and ECLIPSE II (Environnement 
et CLImat du PaSsé: histoire et Evolution). This study has been 
supported by BQR grant « Mise en place d’équipements pour la 
thermochronologie basse température en Sciences de la Terre »
from the Université de Toulouse. We thank PeruPetro SA for 
providing seismic reﬂ ection proﬁ les and for permission to pub-
lish their imagery. We also thank Carina Hoorn for inviting us 
to contribute to this book. We ﬁ nally thank T.E. Jordan and 
J. Hovikoski for their interesting comments that helped to 
improve this chapter.

The Amazon drainage basin is a highly heterogeneous region in 
which, from the Miocene to the present day, geological history, 
landscape, climate, soils and biota have been closely related to 
large-scale subduction processes of the Nazca-South America con-
vergence system (Roddaz 2004). Before 4 Ma, the role of the Nazca 
Ridge subduction seems to have been restricted to the Andes (e.g. 
Hampel 2002; McNulty & Farber 2002; Rousse et al. 2003) and the 
ridge does not inﬂ uence the Amazonian foreland basin develop-
ment (see Fig. 6.6a). In contrast, Pliocene-Pleistocene landscape 
evolution of the western Amazonian foreland basin coincides 
with the onset of the Nazca Ridge ﬂ at subduction (see Fig. 6.6b) 
(Espurt et al. 2007). Thus, the geomorphic Fitzcarrald Arch 
regional uplift may have induced large-scale modiﬁ cations of 
the hydrological, erosional and sedimentological processes in the 
Amazon drainage basin since the Pliocene. The modern drainage 
network of the Fitzcarrald Arch eroded Neogene sediments away 
from an area greater than 400,000 km2(see Fig. 6.2). These erosive 
processes induced new rivers in the Fitzcarrald Arch area, which 
are noticeably enriched in smectite, indicating strong recycling of 
Miocene sediments (Guyot et al. 2007). In any budget related to 
Andean erosion, the suspended sediment yields from the erosion 
of the Fitzcarrald Arch must be taken into account in order not to 
overestimate the erosion rates of the Andes.
Tropical rainforests are well known for their high biodiversity 
(Groombridge 1992; Hooghiemstra & Van der Hammen 1998). 
The Fitzcarrald Arch uplift could have played a major role in the 
distribution patterns of the modern Amazon biota (e.g. Lougheed 
et al. 1999; Patton et al. 2000; Montufar & Pintaud 2006). Indeed, 
the uplift and dissection of sedimentary series of the Fitzcarrald 
Arch created a dynamic edaphic mosaic in the area that sustained 
high diversity.
The Neogene geological formations outcropping on the 
Fitzcarrald Arch area are various and complex, and have dis-
tinctive lithological (e.g. Miocene Madre de Dios clays vs 
Pliocene-Pleistocene conglomerates), hydrological and geochem-
ical characteristics (Guyot et al. 2007) with associated fertile soils. 
This edaphic control probably induces a distinct ﬂ oral and faunal 
development, such as endemic species (e.g. Linna 2001; Klemola 
2003; Ruokolainen et al. 2005), and probably controls the activities 
of autochthonous tribes (Hovikoski et al. 2007). At about 8 Ma, 
the modern eastward Amazon River system had become estab-
lished (Hoorn et al. 1995; Dobson et al. 1997, 2001; Wesselingh & 
Salo 2006). The Fitzcarrald Arch uplift has created a formidable 
NE–SW-trending barrier within the Amazonian lowland forest 
since Pliocene times. This uplift also contributed to producing a 
drained area and may have permitted the development of isolated
